Abnormal QRS complexes can indicate a conduction delay, which is an ominous sign related to cardiac arrest. The mention of "P-wave absence" could suggest hyperkalemia-related changes, which falls under Category 6, but since the focus is primarily on QRS irregularities, Category 4 is more applicable. The alignment is strong due to the direct reference to QRS abnormalities, which are a critical indicator of conduction delays linked to imminent cardiac arrest.

The claim mentions "potentially abnormal QRS complexes" and "P-wave absence," which aligns with the QRS Widening (Conduction Delay) category. QRS widening or the absence of P-waves can indicate severe conduction delays or arrhythmic events that may precede cardiac arrest.
